results.headline: Those Killer Fish Bite Back

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Piranha 3DD

results.summary_short: In “Piranha 3DD,” a sequel to a 2010 horror parody, killer fish attack a water park while David Hasselhoff looks on.

results.headline: Ignoring Laws of Physics as They Run Across Roofs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Cat in Paris

results.summary_short: “A Cat in Paris,” an animated film by the French team of Jean-Loup Felicioli and Alain Gagnol, follows a little girl and some blustery gangsters.

results.headline: The Darker Side of the Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snow White and the Huntsman

results.summary_short: “Snow White and the Huntsman,” directed by Rupert Sanders, puts some menace back into the classic tale.

results.headline: Turning a Charity Symbol Into a Corporate Logo

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pink Ribbons, Inc.

results.summary_short: The documentary “Pink Ribbons, Inc.” examines the link between breast cancer research fund-raising and profits for the cause’s corporate sponsors.

results.headline: Beating the System With Tainted Brownies and Tainted Minds

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of High School

results.summary_short: The stoner comedy “High School” follows the class valedictorian and his pothead buddy as they learn of plans for mandatory drug testing.

results.headline: Seeking Balm for Soul in Boat Going Nowhere

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hide Away

results.summary_short: Scarred by tragedy, a software executive seeks solace by fixing up a boat in this fable.

results.headline: A Dying Village Gets a Curious Visitor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Found Memories

results.summary_short: In “Found Memories,” a photographer shows up in a town that time, and the rest of Brazil, forgot.

results.headline: Of Saints and Sinners, in a Fevered Mexico

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For Greater Glory

results.summary_short: “For Greater Glory,” by Dean Wright, is an epic of the Cristero War in Mexico, when Roman Catholics fought back against government suppression.

results.headline: From Managing a Casino to Coaching Lacrosse

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crooked Arrows

results.summary_short: A reluctant new coach faces the challenge of leading a team of unhappy youths to a lacrosse championship.

results.headline: A Country Singer Comes Out, Very Carefully

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wish Me Away

results.summary_short: The documentary “Chely Wright: Wish Me Away” chronicles the steps to Ms. Wright’s announcement of her homosexuality.

results.headline: An Obnoxious Guy Meets His Comeuppance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 6 Month Rule

results.summary_short: The “6 Month Rule” doesn’t work out so well for its promulgator, an unpleasant womanizer named Tyler.

results.headline: A Palestinian Whose Cameras Are Witnesses and Casualties of Conflict

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 5 Broken Cameras

results.summary_short: “5 Broken Cameras” is a personal documentary about life in a Palestinian village up against the Israeli security fence.

results.headline: Jaunt Through Fallout Zone Goes (Shock!) Awry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chernobyl Diaries

results.summary_short: Six foreign tourists in Ukraine encounter carnivorous humanoids in “Chernobyl Diaries.”

results.headline: A Field Trip to End All Field Trips, Literally, for These Ninth Graders

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle Royale

results.summary_short: “Battle Royale” has been compared to Gary Ross’s adaptation of Suzanne Collins’s “Hunger Games,” though it emphasizes pulp and melodrama over political allegory.

results.headline: Scouting Out a Paradise: Books, Music and No Adults

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moonrise Kingdom

results.summary_short: Wes Anderson’s new film, “Moonrise Kingdom,” is a self-consciously once-upon-a-time tale of two romantic 12-year-olds who create their own paradise by running away.

results.headline: Three Young Men Reunited in Grief

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Redlegs

results.summary_short: In “Redlegs,” by Brandon Harris, three friends are galvanized by the death of a buddy.

results.headline: Filmmaker Puts His Mental Illness on Screen
results.display_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie

results.summary_short: “OC87” is a man’s portrait of his journey through mental illness.

results.headline: An Animated Mahabharata Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arjun

results.summary_short: In “Arjun — The Warrior Prince,” Arnab Chaudhuri animates a story from the ancient Indian Mahabharata epic.

results.headline: Helping a White Man Relearn Joie de Vivre

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Untouchables

results.summary_short: “The Intouchables” is an ingratiating French comedy of cross-racial friendship.

results.headline: Temptation Dominates the Road to Recovery

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oslo, August 31st

results.summary_short: “Oslo, August 31st” is a day in the life of a recovering drug addict, Anders. You are never sure what he will do next, and it is clear that he is not, either.
